botanical_details.genus: Vaccinium can be evergreen or deciduous shrubs or small trees, with simple leaves and small, bell- or urn-shaped flowers followed by juicy, sometimes edible berries

how_to_grow.cultivation: Plant in a sheltered site in well-drained, moisture-retentive, acidic soil, (pH 4.5-5.5) in sun or part shade. Alternatively grow in containers or raised beds filled with ericaceous compost such as John Innes Ericaceous. Pot grown plants benefit from winter protection. For further details see blueberry cultivation
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by taking softwood cuttings in late spring or semi-ripe cuttings in early summer
how_to_grow.pruning: More mature plants benefit from regular pruning. See blueberry pruning
how_to_grow.pests: May be susceptible to vine weevil larvae damage especially if container grown. Protect ripening fruit with netting from birds
how_to_grow.diseases: May be susceptible to Powdery mildews and root rot. Chlorosis due to iron and manganese deficiency may be a problem – see nutrient deficiencies
